title: Sadako Ogata | UC Berkeley Political Science

quotes: Ogata was born on Sept. 16, 1927, in Tokyo, the eldest daughter of Toyoichi Nakamura, a diplomat in the foreign ministry, and Tsuneko Yoshizawa, a granddaughter of Tsuyoshi Inukai, a prime minister who was assassinated in 1932.

Ogata was born on Sept. 16, 1927, in Tokyo, the eldest daughter of Toyoichi Nakamura, a diplomat in the foreign ministry, and Tsuneko Yoshizawa, a granddaughter of Tsuyoshi Inukai, a prime minister who was assassinated in 1932.
But with her strong scholarship in international relations and her fluency in English, she was appointed to a Japanese delegation to the United Nations General Assembly in 1968.

In 1978, she was awarded the Elise and Walter A. Haas International Award, which honors a Berkeley alumnus/a who is a native, citizen, and resident of another country and who has a distinguished record of service.
In 1995, Ogata was awarded the Philadelphia Liberty Medal, an annual award given by the National Constitution Centre of the US, which recognizes 'leadership in the pursuit of freedom'.
In a 1992 interview with Institute of International Studies, Ogata spoke fondly of her time at Berkeley.

organizations.name: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)
quotes: Refugees (UNHCR). Well-respected by UN staff and world leaders alike, she was described by her colleagues as a 'five-foot giant' for her formidable negotiating skills and ability to confront hostile factions.

organizations.name: University of the Sacred Heart
quotes: After earning her Bachelor’s degree from the University of the Sacred Heart in Tokyo, a Rotary Foundation fellowship took her to the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service in Washington, where she pursued a master’s degree.

organizations.name: Rotary Foundation
quotes: After earning her Bachelor’s degree from the University of the Sacred Heart in Tokyo, a Rotary Foundation fellowship took her to the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service in Washington, where she pursued a master’s degree.

quotes: After earning her Bachelor’s degree from the University of the Sacred Heart in Tokyo, a Rotary Foundation fellowship took her to the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service in Washington, where she pursued a master’s degree.

organizations.name: University of California, Berkeley
quotes: Ogata earned a doctorate in political science from the University of California, Berkeley, specializing in political theory, international relations, and East Asian affairs.

organizations.name: United Nations General Assembly
quotes: But with her strong scholarship in international relations and her fluency in English, she was appointed to a Japanese delegation to the United Nations General Assembly in 1968.

organizations.name: United Nations Children’s Fund
quotes: Ogata subsequently took on roles as a minister in Japan’s mission to the United Nations and as chairwoman of the executive board of the United Nations Children’s Fund.

Ogata was born on Sept. 16, 1927, in Tokyo, the eldest daughter of Toyoichi Nakamura, a diplomat in the foreign ministry, and Tsuneko Yoshizawa, a granddaughter of Tsuyoshi Inukai, a prime minister who was assassinated in 1932.

After earning her Bachelor’s degree from the University of the Sacred Heart in Tokyo, a Rotary Foundation fellowship took her to the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service in Washington, where she pursued a master’s degree.
Ogata earned a doctorate in political science from the University of California, Berkeley, specializing in political theory, international relations, and East Asian affairs.
